Situation1: Their family members have recently emphasized the importance of maintaining long-held customs.
Expectation2: Provide spiritual guidance and counseling to individuals in need
Situation2: A member of the community has scheduled an appointment to discuss a persistent personal struggle.
Story:
I sat at the kitchen table, my stepmother’s voice echoing in my mind: “This year, you must lead the family prayer and help with the ancestral offerings. It’s your turn to honor our traditions.” Her eyes had been hopeful, almost pleading, as if my participation would finally knit me into the fabric of this family. I wanted to please her, to show my respect for the customs that meant so much to them, even if they still felt foreign to me.

But as I glanced at my phone, a message blinked on the screen—a reminder of my appointment at the church. Mrs. Lee, a longtime parishioner, was coming to seek counsel. She’d confided in me last week about her struggles with loneliness and doubt, and I knew how much she needed someone to listen, to offer comfort and spiritual guidance.

The clock ticked closer to the time when both worlds would demand me. My heart pounded with the weight of expectation: my family’s hope for unity and tradition, my calling to serve those in spiritual need. I felt torn, caught between the longing to belong and the duty to guide, unsure which path to follow.
